I did what I should of done prior to my last posting.  I went back and rere=
ad the NEAT chapter from Mat Buckland's book "AI Techniques for Game Progra=
mming."

Then it finally clicked.  m_vecInnovs contains the "historical rec=
ord of ANY structural changes" to all of the genes in the population of spe=
cies.

Now I have some specific questions about the Crossover Operator and =
the example in Figure 11.20. 

In the case of the excess gene of the Parent=
 2 (dad), Innovation 15, a link between node 3 and 9.  At the point when st=
epping through each parents genes until the end of both is reached allowing=
 Link Gene 12 of Parent 1 (mum) to be compared to Link Gene 15.  

The If E=
lse structure in the Cga:Crossover function results would be.

    //the en=
d of mum's genes have been reached
    if ((curMum =3D=3D mum.EndOfGenes())=
&&(curDad !=3D dad.EndOfGenes()))

// if ( (TRUE) && (FALSE)) =3D FALSE Thi=
s case not selected

    //the end of dads's genes have been reached

 if ((curDad =3D=3D dad.EndOfGenes())&&(curMum !=3D mum.EndOfGenes()))

// =
else if ((TRUE) && (FALSE)) =3D FALSE This case not selected

 innovation number is less than dads
    else if (curMum->InnovationID < cu=
rDad->InnovationID)
//Because mums innovation number is less than dads, thi=
s case is selected.

   So even if dad is the fittest gene Gene 15 is not a=
dded to the baby genes.  How then are the excess genes of the fittest paren=
t inherited?


Another question.  If for example for the first genes in mum=
 and dad have the same innovation number the baby gene is randomly grabbed =
from either parent.  But since the gene is disabled in one parent couldn't =
the resulting crossover phenotype have a disconnected node 1?

Hope this ma=
kes sense.

Thanks

Raymond
